ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Polycrystalline GaSb films prepared by the coevaporation technique

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Instrumentation Science, USIC Building

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Gallium antimonide (GaSb) films were deposited onto fused silica and n-Si (100) substrates by coevaporating Ga and Sb from appropriate evaporation sources. The films were polycrystalline in nature. The size and the shape of the grains varied with the change in the substrate temperature during deposition. The average surface roughness of the films was estimated to be 10 nm. Grain boundary trap states varied between 2×1012 and 2.2×1012 cm−2 while barrier height at the grain boundaries varied between 0.09 eV and 0.10 eV for films deposited at higher temperatures. Stress in the films decreased for films deposited at higher temperatures. XPS studies indicated two strong peaks located at ∼543 eV and ∼1121 eV for Sb 3d3/2 and Ga 2p3/2 core-level spectra, respectively. The PL spectra measured at 300 K was dominated by a strong peak located ∼0.55 eV followed by two low intensity peaks ∼0.63 eV and 0.67 eV. A typical n-Si/GaSb photovoltaic cell fabricated here indicated V oc∼311 mV and J∼29.45 mA/cm2, the density of donors (N d)∼3.87×1015 cm−3, built in potential (V bi)∼0.48 V and carrier life time (τ)∼28.5 ms. Impedance spectroscopy measurements indicated a dielectric relaxation time ∼100 μs.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Gallium antimonide (GaSb) is an interesting material due to its unusual characteristics [1–6], which facilitates its use in semiconductor-based devices. This material has a direct band gap at 0.7 eV, matching with the 1.55 μm window in the silica fibers. It has been fruitfully used in designing photonic devices such as laser diodes and photodetectors, and optical communications [2]. Moreover, it is also a very good substrate for semiconductor integrated devices, because of its lattice parameter (6.09 Å) being very near to that of other semiconductors such as InAs, GaAlAs, and CdTe [3]. The other most promising applications of GaSb is in the development of thermophotovoltaic (TPV) cells based on GaSb materials, either in bulk or in thin-film configurations [4]. Fabrication of GaSb photodiodes with a high breakdown voltage was reported by Sridharan et al. [2]. However, the major drawback concerning the use of GaSb in the TPV technology is the high cost of these cells, which is related to the GaSb substrates itself, the monocrystalline epitaxial layers, and the processing on the device. One possibility of reducing the wafer cost is the use of polycrystalline thin film materials and cheap substrates for the reduction of the processing cost. All these applications have made gallium antimonide (GaSb) a material of prime interest in recent years.

Various deposition techniques had been adopted by a number of groups to deposit GaSb thin films [1–8]. But large scale deployment of this material for device applications is being deterred by the dearth of process technology for obtaining the material in polycrystalline thin film form by low-cost and the scalable method. There are only two reports [3, 9] on synthesizing GaSb films by the coevaporation technique. Zaixiang et al. [3] reported optical and electrical properties of polycrystalline GaSb thin films, grown successfully by coevaporation on soda-lime glass substrates. These films deposited at a substrate temperature of 560 °C were preferentially oriented in the (111) direction and the average grain size was ∼500 nm. The results suggested that polycrystalline GaSb thin film would be a good candidate for the use as a cheap material in thermophotovoltaic cells. Jiang-ming et al. [9] deposited GaSb polycrystalline thin films on ordinary glass substrates by the coevaporation technique and reported the structural properties and optoelectronic properties.

Undoped GaSb is usually p-type with a thermal equilibrium concentration of holes ranging from 1015 to 1017 cm−3 [5, 10]. The photo response of this material makes it very useful in the design of a variety of device architectures, including photo detectors, resonant tunneling structures, and other quantum devices [2, 3, 5]. The performance of the material in this case depends on the lifetime of free charge carriers generated by the interaction of light with the material, referred to as the excess carrier lifetime (τ). The excess carrier lifetime is in general determined by the recombination rate of the minority charge carriers in the bulk and at the surface. Thus, the use of polycrystalline thin film materials along with cheap substrates for the reduction of the processing cost may be hindered by the presence of grain boundaries and associated grain boundary trap states that would modulate the electron transport process in these films. Additionally, a considerable amount of thermal stress, which would arise out of the mismatch between thermal expansion coefficients of the film (α film) and substrate (α subs) when the films are deposited at higher substrate temperatures would also modulate carrier life time. Thus, it appears that the information reported so far on GaSb in polycrystalline thin film form is far from comprehensive and complete. The need of a reliable, low-cost, and scalable process technology for the synthesis of GaSb in polycrystalline thin film form is needed to expand the use of this material in different device technologies. A successful attempt of synthesizing GaSb in polycrystalline form by coevaporating Ga and Sb under controlled evaporation condition is presented here. The films were characterized by measuring optical, microstructural, photoluminescence, and compositional properties. Information related to stress and grain boundary properties are documented. Photovoltaic properties were also recorded for a n-Si/GaSb structure fabricated with the films deposited as above.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para: GaSb films were deposited onto fused silica (quartz) and n-Si (100) substrates (1–5 Ω/□) by coevaporating Ga (99.995 %) and Sb (99.995 %) from two independent indirectly heated alumina crucibles at a system pressure better than 10−6 Torr. The films were deposited at three different substrate temperatures ranging from 573 K to 773 K during deposition. The rate of evaporation was monitored by a quartz crystal oscillator separately for both Ga and Sb. The quartz crystal was inserted inside the vacuum chamber vertically above the basket heater keeping the distance from the heater to the quartz crystal and the substrate same. Then evaporation rate was calibrated against the current flowing through the individual basket heaters used for evaporating Ga and Sb separately. Heavy charges were loaded in the crucibles to ensure thermal stability of the sources. Thus, one can nearly dial in the evaporation rates for depositing GaSb films with desired composition.

Compositional information was obtained by EDAX (Oxford Instruments’ INCA Energy 250 Microanalysis System), which indicated that the films were nearly stoichiometric. The surface morphology of the films was studied by Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FESEM) (Carl Zeiss SUPRA® 55 with GEMINI® Technology with resolution ∼0.8 nm @ 15 kV). AFM pictures were recorded by using a Nanosurf Easy Scan 2 atomic force microscope in contact mode. X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies were carried out by using Rigaku MiniFlex XRD (0.154 nm Cu K α line) to obtain the microstructural information. XPS measurements were carried out to study the surface chemical properties of the films. Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out using a M/s SPECS (Germany) make spectrometer at a system pressure of ∼4×1010 Torr. Al Kα line was used as the X-ray source at 1486.74 eV. Photoluminescence (PL) measurements were recorded at 300 K by using a 300 W xenon arc lamp as the emission source. An excitation of 0.82 eV was applied by using a monochromator. A Hamamatsu photo multiplier along with a 1/4 m monochromator was used as the detecting system.

Section2.Heading: Microstructural studies
Section2.Para: The GaSb films were deposited at fixed evaporation rates for both the elemental materials while the substrate temperature during deposition was varied to impart sufficient adatom mobility to produce ordered structure. Considering Komnik’s [11, 12] observation that 1/3T m (temperature of melting) may essentially be the lower limit below, at which the adatoms may not have sufficient mobility. Keeping in view of temperature at which vapor pressure of GaSb ∼10−6 Torr (which is also the system pressure during deposition) being 770 °C, the substrate temperature during deposition was varied between 573 K and 773 K. A set of three films were deposited at ∼573 K, 673 K and 773 K keeping the time of deposition same (25 min) for all the films.

The FESEM pictures of GaSb films on n-Si(100) substrates deposited as above are shown in Fig. 1(a–c). One may observe gradual grain growth with the increase in substrate temperature during deposition. The films were found to be compact in nature and the histograms (shown in the inset of Fig. 1a–c) indicated more or less narrow distribution of the grain sizes constituting the film. Increase in grain size with increase in substrate temperature is depicted in FESEM pictures (Fig. 1d). The AFM picture of the film deposited at 773 K is shown in the inset of Fig. 1d. The grain size increased from 65 nm to 106 nm (Table 1) as the substrate temperature increased from 573 K to 773 K (Fig. 1d). The grain size increased nearly monotonically with deposition temperature (T s) and tended to saturate above T s>773 K which is being the temperature at which the vapor pressure of GaSb is ∼10−6 Torr. It is known that at T s>(2/3)T m condensation occurs via vapor to liquid to solid transformation while at T s<(2/3)T m, transformation is directly from vapor to solid. Thus, as the system pressure during deposition is ∼10−6 Torr, further increase in deposition temperature may culminate in depositing of nonstoichiometric films. The compositional studies were carried out by EDAX measurements and the films were found to be nearly stoichiometric. Ga/Sb ratio varied between 0.91 and 1.03 (Table 1).

Section2.Heading: XPS studies
Section2.Para:
Figure 2a shows the general survey x-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) spectrum of a representative GaSb film deposited on n-Si(100) substrate at 773 K. The XPS general survey scans of all the films were found to be the same. A low intensity peak for C1s could be located at ∼288.03 eV. This is shifted by 3.63 eV from its standard value toward higher binding energy. This shift of ∼3.63 eV toward higher energy from the standard peak value is reflected in all the peaks (Fig. 2a). The survey spectra are dominated by two pairs of strong peaks 537 eV (Fig. 2b) and at ∼1117 eV (Fig. 2c) for Sb 3d3/2 and Ga 2p3/2 core-level spectra, respectively [14, 15]. The above intense peak ∼1117 eV would correspond to Ga–Sb bond in GaSb. There are a few lower intensity peaks for Ga3d5/2 and Ga3p1/2 at ∼21 eV and 107 eV, respectively. The peak ∼537 eV overlaps with that of O1s. Oxygen peak arises due to physisorbed oxygen at the surface. A very low intensity broad peak ∼21 eV of Ga 3d peak is observed (inset of Fig. 2c). This peak could be deconvoluted (not shown) to two peaks corresponding to the binding energies of GaSb and Ga2O3. This observation is in commensurate with that reported by Liu et al. [15] from their XPS studies of the high purity GaSb nanoparticles contained in the SiO2 matrices. A low intensity peak of Sb 4d around ∼39 eV (not marked) is also observed. These peaks are associated with the binding energies of Sb as Sb2O3 and Sb2O5 [15]. Low intensity of the oxide peaks of Ga and Sb signify the fact that a lesser amount of the oxides are present in the sample. These could be reasoned to the physisorption of oxygen during sample handling. The peak at ∼107 eV appears with another peak ∼108 eV corresponding to SiO2 bond associated with the Si 2p core [15]. A less intense peak ∼1148 eV corresponding to Ga 2p1/2 peak is also observed.

Section2.Heading: Photoluminescence and optical studies
Section2.Para:
PL spectra were recorded at 300 K for all the GaSb films on the quartz substrate with excitation energy of 0.82 eV and spectrum for three representative films deposited at 773 K, 673 K, and 573 K is shown in Fig. 3a The PL spectra were dominated by a very strong peak located ∼0.556 eV followed by two low intensity peaks located ∼0.626 eV and 0.667 eV. The observed PL peak located ∼0.667 eV is due to near band edge transitions while the other peaks located at lower energies could be ascribed to DA transitions due to native defects. Considering the observation of Xu [16], it may be concluded that the PL peaks at 0.626 eV and 0.556 eV have originated from gallium vacancy (V Ga) with charge states 0 and −2, respectively.

It may be noted here that the transmittance spectra (Fig. 3b) of the GaSb films do not indicate interference fringes needed for the determination of the thickness. This would render the determination of the optical constants difficult and uncertain. Apart from ellipsometric studies, simultaneous determination of the thickness (d) of the thin film and obtaining information about its complex refractive index (η=n+ik, where n = refractive index and k = extinction coefficient) is quite difficult experimentally as in most practical cases, like the one under consideration in this communication. The Kramers–Kronig (KK) model would seem to overcome this impasse elegantly [19]. Subsequently, Xue et al. [20] modified the KK theory successfully and able to measure the spectral dependence of the real and imaginary part of the complex dielectric constant for transparent ZnO:Al thin films with different Al doping concentration. As thickness was an input to obtain the optical parameters so it was measured separately by Xue et al. This problem could be overcome by simultaneous computation of the optical parameters as discussed in [21].

The values for the real part of refractive index (n) and the extinction coefficient (k) of the GaSb system under study have been computed as above [21]. The real and complex part of the dielectric constant (ε 1 and ε 2 respectively) have been estimated by using the relations:

Section2.Heading: Grain boundary parameters from below band gap absorption studies
Section2.Para: Grain boundary phenomena in polycrystalline films are known to influence the optical absorption band tails. In the polycrystalline material, the absorption coefficient at the band edge (E g) is not so sharp compared to that for crystalline material. Polycrystalline films are known to be the aggregates of randomly distributed grains and grain boundary regions. The grain boundary regions would contain a large amount of defect states which become charged after trapping free carriers from the neighboring grains. Additionally, considerable amount of thermal stress arising out of the mismatch between thermal expansion coefficients of the film (α film) and substrate (α subs) would also be present. This would culminate in a fluctuating potential, and hence the band gap (E g) and manifest in the existence of additional indirect optical transitions below the fundamental band gap of the material. Modification of the absorption edge due to grain boundaries and mechanical stresses in polycrystalline semiconductors has been considered in details by several authors [25–32]. The details of the processes have already been reported elsewhere [28, 32, 33].

Using the subscript zero to indicate quantities at the band gap, the normalized total absorption could be expressed as
6
$$ \frac{A}{A_{0}} = \frac{\int_{0}^{\infty} P(D)\,dD\int_{0}^{L} \alpha (\nu,F)r^{2}\,dr}{\int_{0}^{\infty} P(D)\,dD\int_{0}^{L} \alpha_{0}(F)r^{2}\,dr}, $$ where P(D) is the probability of a crystallite having a diameter D. It can be noted that here that α appearing in Eq. (6) is a function of both phonon energy and electric field in the crystallites. Simplified expressions for the two limiting cases, i.e., for small crystallites and for large crystallites, were also obtained by them.

For large crystallites, the surface states may all be considered to be occupied by charge carriers, so that the grains become partially depleted of carriers and the electric field close to the surface will decay exponentially. In such a case, considering a Gaussian distribution of crystalline size (D) as shown in Eq. (6), we may express absorption coefficient due electric field across the grain boundary to A/A 0, i.e.

This would influence the electronic structure and hence the below-band-edge optical absorption processes as a whole in form of electrostatic fluctuations of the band edge [28, 32, 33]. We have computed the normalized absorption coefficients (α/α 0) below the band gap as a function of energy. Figure 5a shows the experimental plots of normalized absorption coefficients (α/α 0) below the band gap of a representative GaSb film deposited at 773 K. As the contribution due to the thermal disorder for any material at a specific temperature (say the room temperature at which optical absorption has been recorded) is fixed, the ultimate shape of (α/α 0) vs. (E g−hν) plot will depend on the amount of the intrinsic disorder or the density of the defect states present in the film. In computing the theoretical plots, we have used the bulk values of m ∗, intrinsic charge carrier density, while utilized the values of E g, thickness, refractive indices (n) obtained from experimental measurements carried out in this paper. The only variable was the grain diameter and grain size distribution. Using Eqs. (8), (9), different grain boundary parameters (Q t and E b) were estimated from the best fit theoretical curve (Fig. 5a) corresponding to the experimental data of (α/α 0) vs. (E g−hν), α 0 being the value of α at E g. The different parameters used for the above theoretical simulation are given in Table 2. The values of Q t and E b are given in Table 1. Change in the values of Q t and E b for films for films deposited at a different substrate temperature during deposition indicated interesting information for the films. It may be observed that the barrier height increased slightly for films deposited at higher temperatures while the density of trap states decreased in films deposited at successively higher temperatures. The films being highly resistive, the charge carrier density in the films will be low. This would mean that films deposited at lower substrate temperatures having higher density of grain boundary trap states will be partially filled and the grains will be fully depleted of charge carriers. This would culminate in lower barrier heights at the grain boundary region. As the density of trap states decreased with grain growth in films deposited at higher substrate temperature during deposition, the trap states would be fully charged leaving the grains partially depleted of charge carriers. This has been reflected in the increase in barrier height at the grain boundaries for films deposited at higher substrate temperature during deposition.

Variation of stress in the films with grain size and density of trap states (Q t), thus evaluated [31] are shown in Fig. 5b. It may be noted that the stress varied between 0.036 to 0.009 GPa and decreased for films deposited at higher temperature for GaSb films, i.e., with increase in grain size (Fig. 4b and Table 1). This result is in commensurate with the fact that at a reasonable deposition rate, the adatoms will have sufficient mobility to align themselves in stress free conditions before being buried by the oncoming surge of adatoms during deposition. Further, with increased grain size, density of trap states will decrease resulting in decrease in mechanical stress in these films (Fig. 5b).

Section2.Heading: Cell characteristics
Section2.Para:
Figure 6a shows the J–V characteristics of the n-Si/GaSb (645 nm) cells and Fig. 6b shows spectral response of the cells while Fig. 6c shows the Mott–Schottky plot. It can be seen from Fig. 6b that in the spectral response the photoelectromotive force is generated for photons with higher energies than about 1.2 eV. This corresponds to the absorption edge and the band gap of Si rather than that of GaSb. This would suggest that the characteristics of the solar cell would reflect the properties of Si rather than those of GaSb. The maximum efficiency achieved was 5.02 % for all the cells with nonoptimized GaSb thickness with V oc∼311 mV and J sc∼29.45 mA/cm2 under 60 mW/cm2 illumination conditions. The cells had poor fill factor ∼0.30–0.35, which indicated that cells fabricated with optimized layer thicknesses would yield efficient PV cells. Straight line plots (Fig. 6c) of 1/C 2−V indicated decent interface while the spectral response indicated good blue absorption in the visible range, which decreased in the NIR range. The density of donors (N d∼3.87×1015 cm−3) and built in potential (V bi∼0.48 V) were computed from the slope and the intercept of the linear portion of 1/C 2−V plots.

The lifetime of photo-generated excess minority carriers is an important parameter in solar cell design. The overall energy conversion efficiency of a photovoltaic cell is critically dependent upon the base region minority carrier lifetime of the cell. Life time could be obtained by measuring the variation of the open-circuit voltage (V oc) decay, which was originally introduced by Gossick [34], and subsequently studied by several others [35–37]. Gossick’s technique involves creating excess minority carriers in a junction device using an external excitation provided by a brief forward current and then monitoring V oc after the excitation has been abruptly terminated. Minority carrier lifetime can be determined by analyzing the resultant V oc decay curve. In brief, upon illumination free electrons and holes are generated, and separated by the potential barrier of the p–n junction. An open-circuit voltage is developed across the junction. When the illumination is switched off, the excess carrier concentration is decreased due to the electron and hole recombination. The decrease in carrier concentration can be understood by the equation shown below [38, 39]:
16
$$ dn/dt = -R = - (n-n_{0} )/\tau. $$
n 0 and n are the equilibrium and nonequilibrium electron concentrations in the region of p-type conductivity. t and τ are the time and the carrier lifetime, respectively. R is the carrier recombination rate. Commonly R is a nonlinear function of n and it can be presented as R=(n−n 0)/τ. Here, τ varies nonlinearly with n. The rate at which the open-circuit voltage decays with time depends on the electrons exchange between the conduction and valence bands [40, 41].

The time dependence of V oc decay can be described by the exponential function [42]:
17
$$ V_{\mathrm{oc}}(t) = V_{\mathrm{oc}}(0) \exp(-t/\tau). $$ Thus, the minority carrier life time can be calculated from the equation shown below [43]:
18
$$ \tau = \frac{2 kT}{q}\bigl[1/(dV_{\mathrm{oc}}/dt)\bigr]. $$

Figure 6d shows the optical response curve of GaSb solar cell using a light of 1 second pulse duration and 60 mW/cm2 intensity generated from a pulsed white light source. From Eq. (8), the estimated carrier life time (τ) was ∼28.5 ms.

Section2.Heading: Impedance spectroscopy
Section2.Para:
The real and complex impedance of the device as a function of test frequency under dark and illumination conditions were shown in Fig. 7a. Photo induced charge separation is associated with an increase in the dielectric constant of the active material and decrease in the device resistance. The relation between the real and imaginary components of impedance, Z′ and Z″, respectively, (Cole–Cole plots) is shown in Fig. 7b. The nature of the Cole–Cole plots is one impedance semicircular arc. A single semicircular arc would mean that the material has formed in one uniform layer instead of a bilayer structure. With increasing frequency Z′ decreases and Z″ shows a peak at f max where the semicircular arc is maximum. Thus, the complex impedance plot shows one semicircular arc representing the bulk properties of the grains. The electrical contribution of the grains was introduced by using a simple equivalent circuit with parallel combination of a resistance (R eq) and a capacitor (C eq) with the diameter of the semicircle representing the resistance as shown in Fig. 6a. The capacitance (C eq) was calculated using the relation:
19
$$ \varOmega \tau = 2\pi f_{\max} R_{\mathrm{eq}} C_{\mathrm{eq}} =1. $$ The capacitance value computed from the above was ∼11.4×10−9 F.
Fig. 7
(a) Real parts of impedance with frequency of a device based on n-Si/GaSb under dark and 60 mW/cm2 illumination conditions, while inset shows complex impedance with frequency under dark and illumination; (b) Cole–Cole plots between the real and imaginary parts of impedance of that device under dark and 60 mW/cm2 illumination conditions and (c) Dielectric constant versus frequency plots of the complex impedance of a device based on n-Si/GaSb under same dark and illumination conditions

The Cole–Cole plots for n-Si/GaSb cells device remains semicircular under both dark and illumination. When the device was illuminated, photocurrent flowed through the device and the diameter of the semicircle is reduced. This is due to the semiconducting nature of the active layer in which the resistance decreases with an increase in the applied voltage. The diameter, however, reduced by more than 90 % in case of illumination. This large decrease in device resistance upon illumination may assert the presence of free carriers, which appeared due to excitation at different interfaces as well as photo induced electron transfer from bulk Si to GaSb.

Frequency dependent capacitance of the device has been modeled as a parallel combination of a resistance and a capacitor (Fig. 7b). The dielectric constant of the active layer could be obtained from the value of capacitance, area, and thickness of the devices. Figure 7c shows the variation of dielectric constant versus frequency plots of a typical device based on n-Si/GaSb cells under dark and illumination conditions. The result shows that the dielectric constant at any frequency increases upon illumination. This increase is due to photo induced electron transfer similar to electrical polarization, which allows more carriers to accumulate at the electrodes during the impedance measurement.

Dielectric relaxation time (τ 1) can be calculated from critical frequency, f max at which Z″ is maximum obtained from Cole–Cole plot as shown in Fig. 7b. The connection between the dielectric measurement made in frequency domain and that made in time domain is given by the Fourier transform relation expressed as below [44]:
20
$$ \tau_1 = 1/[2\pi f_{\max}]. $$ Thus, using the value of f max from Fig. 6a, τ 1 was computed to be ∼100 μs.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: GaSb films could be deposited by coevaporating Ga and Sb on fused silica and n-Si (100) substrates kept at three different temperatures (T s) during deposition. The surface roughness of the films increased in films deposited at higher T s. Grain size increased with T s. Trap states at the grain boundaries varied between 2.0×10−12 and 2.2×10−12 cm−2 while barrier height at the grain boundaries varied between 0.09 eV and 0.10 eV for films deposited at higher temperatures. Stress in the films decreased for films deposited at higher temperatures. The PL spectra measured at 300 K was dominated by a strong peak located ∼0.55 eV followed by two low intensity peaks located ∼0.63 eV and 0.67 eV. Two strong XPS peaks was observed at ∼543 eV and ∼1121 eV for Sb 3d3/2 and Ga 2p3/2 core-level spectra, respectively. Solar cell efficiency of 5.02 % and fill factor of 0.33 was achieved with n-Si/GaSb structure. The density of donor (N d)∼3.87×1015 cm−3 and built in potential (V ib)∼0.48 V was calculated from 1/C 2−V plot. From the V oc decay measurement, the estimated carrier life time (τ) was 28.5 ms. Impedance spectroscopy measurements indicated a dielectric relaxation time ∼100 μs.
